# _The Lion King_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about Disney's 1994 film. For the upcoming 2019 film of the
same name, see [The Lion King (2019 film)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(2019_film\)
"The Lion King \(2019 film\)"). For the franchise as a whole, see [The Lion
King (franchise)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(franchise\) "The Lion King
\(franchise\)"). For other uses, see [The Lion King
(disambiguation)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(disambiguation\) "The Lion King
\(disambiguation\)").

_**The Lion King**_ is a 1994 American [animated](/wiki/Animation "Animation")
[epic](/wiki/Epic_film "Epic film") [musical](/wiki/Musical_film "Musical
film") film produced by [Walt Disney Feature
Animation](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney Animation
Studios") and released by [Walt Disney Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures
"Walt Disney Pictures"). It is the 32nd [Disney animated feature
film](/wiki/List_of_Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios_films "List of Walt Disney
Animation Studios films"), and the fifth animated film produced during a
period known as the [Disney Renaissance](/wiki/Disney_Renaissance "Disney
Renaissance"). _The Lion King_ was directed by [Roger
Allers](/wiki/Roger_Allers "Roger Allers") and [Rob Minkoff](/wiki/Rob_Minkoff
"Rob Minkoff"), produced by [Don Hahn](/wiki/Don_Hahn "Don Hahn"), and has a
screenplay credited to [Irene Mecchi](/wiki/Irene_Mecchi "Irene Mecchi"),
[Jonathan Roberts](/wiki/Jonathan_Roberts_\(writer\) "Jonathan Roberts
\(writer\)"), and [Linda Woolverton](/wiki/Linda_Woolverton "Linda
Woolverton"). Its original songs were written by composer [Elton
John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John") and lyricist [Tim Rice](/wiki/Tim_Rice
"Tim Rice"), with a score by [Hans Zimmer](/wiki/Hans_Zimmer "Hans Zimmer").
The film features an [ensemble voice cast](/wiki/Ensemble_cast "Ensemble
cast") that includes [Matthew Broderick](/wiki/Matthew_Broderick "Matthew
Broderick"), [James Earl Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones"),
[Jeremy Irons](/wiki/Jeremy_Irons "Jeremy Irons"), [Jonathan Taylor
Thomas](/wiki/Jonathan_Taylor_Thomas "Jonathan Taylor Thomas"), [Moira
Kelly](/wiki/Moira_Kelly "Moira Kelly"), [Nathan Lane](/wiki/Nathan_Lane
"Nathan Lane"), [Ernie Sabella](/wiki/Ernie_Sabella "Ernie Sabella"), [Rowan
Atkinson](/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson "Rowan Atkinson"), [Robert
Guillaume](/wiki/Robert_Guillaume "Robert Guillaume"), [Madge
Sinclair](/wiki/Madge_Sinclair "Madge Sinclair"), [Whoopi
Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi Goldberg"), [Cheech
Marin](/wiki/Cheech_Marin "Cheech Marin"), and [Jim
Cummings](/wiki/Jim_Cummings "Jim Cummings"). The story takes place in a
kingdom of [lions](/wiki/East_African_lion "East African lion") in
[Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa") and was influenced by [William
Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare")'s
_[Hamlet](/wiki/Hamlet "Hamlet")_.

_The Lion King_ tells the story of [Simba](/wiki/Simba "Simba"), a young lion
who is to succeed his father, Mufasa, as King of the Pride Lands; however,
after Simba's uncle Scar (Mufasa's jealous younger brother), murders Mufasa,
Simba is manipulated into thinking he was responsible and flees into
[exile](/wiki/Exile "Exile"). Upon maturation living with [two
wastrels](/wiki/Timon_and_Pumbaa "Timon and Pumbaa"), Simba is given some
valuable perspective from his childhood friend, [Nala](/wiki/Nala_\(Disney\)
"Nala \(Disney\)"), and his [shaman](/wiki/Shaman "Shaman"), Rafiki, before
returning to challenge Scar to end his [tyranny](/wiki/Tyranny "Tyranny") and
take his place in the Circle of Life as the rightful King.

Development of _The Lion King_ began in 1988 during a meeting between [Jeffrey
Katzenberg](/wiki/Jeffrey_Katzenberg "Jeffrey Katzenberg"), [Roy E.
Disney](/wiki/Roy_E._Disney "Roy E. Disney"), and [Peter
Schneider](/wiki/Peter_Schneider_\(film_executive\) "Peter Schneider \(film
executive\)") while promoting _[Oliver& Company](/wiki/Oliver_%26_Company
"Oliver & Company")_ in Europe. [Thomas Disch](/wiki/Thomas_Disch "Thomas
Disch") wrote a [film treatment](/wiki/Film_treatment "Film treatment"), and
Woolverton developed the first scripts while [George
Scribner](/wiki/George_Scribner "George Scribner") was signed on as director,
being later joined by Allers. Production began in 1991 concurrently with
_[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(1995_film\) "Pocahontas \(1995 film\)")_ ,
which wound up attracting most of Disney's top animators. Some time after the
staff traveled to [Hell's Gate National
Park](/wiki/Hell%27s_Gate_National_Park "Hell's Gate National Park") in
[Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya") to research on the film's setting and animals,
Scribner left production disagreeing with the decision to turn the film into a
musical and was replaced by Minkoff. When Hahn joined the project, he was
dissatisfied with the script and the story was promptly rewritten. Nearly 20
minutes of animation sequences were produced at [Disney’s Hollywood
Studios](/wiki/Disney%E2%80%99s_Hollywood_Studios "Disney’s Hollywood
Studios") theme park in Florida. [Computer animation](/wiki/Computer_animation
"Computer animation") was also used in several scenes, most notably in the
[wildebeest](/wiki/Wildebeest "Wildebeest") stampede sequence.

_The Lion King_ was released on June 15, 1994, to a positive reaction from
critics, who praised the film for its music, story, and animation. With a
worldwide gross of $766 million, it finished its theatrical run as the
[highest-grossing release of 1994](/wiki/1994_in_film#Highest_grossing_films
"1994 in film") and the [second highest-grossing film of all
time](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films "List of highest-grossing films").
It is also the [highest-grossing traditionally animated film of all
time](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_animated_films#Traditional_animation
"List of highest-grossing animated films"). _The Lion King_ garnered two
[Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") for its achievement in
music and the [Golden Globe Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe
Award") for [Best Motion Picture – Musical or
Comedy](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_%E2%80%93_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy"). The film
has led to [many derived works](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(franchise\) "The Lion
King \(franchise\)"), such as [a Broadway
adaptation](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(musical\) "The Lion King \(musical\)"); two
[direct-to-video](/wiki/Direct-to-video "Direct-to-video") follow-ups—the
sequel, _[The Lion King II: Simba's
Pride](/wiki/The_Lion_King_II:_Simba%27s_Pride "The Lion King II: Simba's
Pride")_ (1998), and the prequel/[parallel](/wiki/Sequel#Parallel "Sequel"),
_[The Lion King 1½](/wiki/The_Lion_King_1%C2%BD "The Lion King 1½")_ (2004);
two television series, _[Timon and
Pumbaa](/wiki/Timon_and_Pumbaa_\(TV_series\) "Timon and Pumbaa \(TV
series\)")_ and _[The Lion Guard](/wiki/The_Lion_Guard "The Lion Guard")_ ;
and a [3D](/wiki/3D_film "3D film") re-release, in 2011.

In 2016, the film was selected for preservation in the United States [National
Film Registry](/wiki/National_Film_Registry "National Film Registry") by the
[Library of Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress") as
being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant". A
[CGI](/wiki/Computer_animation "Computer animation")
[remake](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(2019_film\) "The Lion King \(2019 film\)") of
the film directed by [Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") is
scheduled for a July 19, 2019 release in the United States.

## Plot

In the Pride Lands of [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"), [Africa](/wiki/Africa
"Africa"), a pride of [lions](/wiki/Lions "Lions") rule over the animal
kingdom from Pride Rock. King Mufasa's newborn son, [Simba](/wiki/Simba
"Simba"), is presented to the assembled animals by Rafiki the baboon (with the
colorful facial marking of a [mandrill](/wiki/Mandrill "Mandrill"))[3] who
serves as [shaman](/wiki/Shamanism "Shamanism") and advisor. Mufasa shows
young Simba the Pride Lands and explains to him the responsibilities of
kingship and the "circle of life" which connects all living things. Mufasa's
younger brother, [Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(The_Lion_King\) "Scar \(The Lion
King\)"), covets the throne and plots to eliminate Mufasa and Simba so he may
become king. He tricks Simba and his best friend Nala—to whom Simba is
betrothed—into exploring a forbidden [elephants'
graveyard](/wiki/Elephants%27_graveyard "Elephants' graveyard"), where they
are attacked by three [spotted hyenas](/wiki/Spotted_hyena "Spotted hyena")
who are in league with Scar. Mufasa is alerted to the danger by his
[majordomo](/wiki/Majordomo "Majordomo"), the [hornbill](/wiki/Hornbill
"Hornbill") Zazu, and rescues the cubs. Though angry with Simba, Mufasa
forgives him and explains that the great kings of the past watch over them
from the night sky, from which he will one day watch over Simba.

Scar sets a trap for his brother and nephew, luring Simba into a gorge and
having the hyenas drive a large herd of [wildebeest](/wiki/Wildebeest
"Wildebeest") into a stampede that will trample him. He informs Mufasa of
Simba's peril, knowing the king will rush to save his son. Mufasa saves Simba
but ends up hanging perilously from the gorge's edge. Scar refuses to help
Mufasa, instead sending him falling to his death. He then convinces Simba that
the tragedy was Simba's own fault and advises him to flee the kingdom. He
orders the hyenas to kill the cub, but Simba escapes. Scar tells the pride
that both Mufasa and Simba were killed in the stampede and steps forward as
the new king, allowing his three hyena minions and the rest of their large
pack to live in the Pride Lands.

Simba collapses in a desert and is rescued by [Timon and
Pumbaa](/wiki/Timon_and_Pumbaa "Timon and Pumbaa"), a [meerkat](/wiki/Meerkat
"Meerkat") and [warthog](/wiki/Common_warthog "Common warthog") who are fellow
outcasts. Simba grows up in the jungle with his two new friends, living a
carefree life under the motto "[hakuna matata](/wiki/Hakuna_matata "Hakuna
matata")" ("no worries" in [Swahili](/wiki/Swahili_language "Swahili
language")). Now a young adult, Simba rescues Timon and Pumbaa from a hungry
lioness who turns out to be Nala. She and Simba reunite and fall in love, and
she urges him to return home, telling him the Pride Lands have become a
drought-stricken wasteland under Scar's reign. Feeling guilty over his
father's death, Simba refuses and storms off. He encounters Rafiki, who tells
him that Mufasa's spirit lives on in Simba. Simba is visited by the ghost of
Mufasa in the night sky, who tells him he must take his rightful place as
king. Realizing he can no longer run from his past, Simba decides to return
home.

Aided by his friends, Simba sneaks past the hyenas at Pride Rock and confronts
Scar. Scar taunts him over his role in Mufasa's death and backs him to the
edge of the rock, where he reveals to Simba that he murdered Mufasa. Enraged,
Simba pins Scar to the ground and forces him to reveal the truth to the rest
of the pride. Timon, Pumbaa, Rafiki, Zazu, and the lionesses fend off the
hyenas while Scar, attempting to escape, is cornered by Simba at the top of
Pride Rock. Scar begs for mercy and attempts to blame the hyenas for his
actions; Simba spares his life, but orders him to leave the Pride Lands
forever. Scar attacks his nephew, but Simba manages to toss him from the top
of the rock. Scar survives the fall, but is attacked and killed by the hyenas,
who overheard his attempt to betray them. With his enemies gone, Simba takes
over the kingship as the rains begin to fall, restoring life to the land.

Later, with Pride Rock restored to its former glory, Rafiki presents Simba and
Nala's newborn cub to the assembled animals, continuing the circle of life.

## Cast

King](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King "List of characters in The

Shenzi, Scar, Ed, Banzai, Rafiki, Young Simba, Mufasa, Young Nala, Sarabi,
Zazu, Sarafina, Timon, and Pumbaa

  * [Matthew Broderick](/wiki/Matthew_Broderick "Matthew Broderick") as [Simba](/wiki/Simba "Simba"), son of Mufasa and Sarabi, who grows up to become King of the Pride Lands. Rock singer [Joseph Williams](/wiki/Joseph_Williams_\(musician\) "Joseph Williams \(musician\)") provided adult Simba's singing voice. [Mark Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn "Mark Henn") and [Ruben A. Aquino](/wiki/Ruben_A._Aquino "Ruben A. Aquino") respectively served as the supervising animators for young and adult Simba.[4]
    * [Jonathan Taylor Thomas](/wiki/Jonathan_Taylor_Thomas "Jonathan Taylor Thomas") voiced young Simba, while [Jason Weaver](/wiki/Jason_Weaver "Jason Weaver") provided the cub's singing voice.[4]
  * [Jeremy Irons](/wiki/Jeremy_Irons "Jeremy Irons") as [Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(The_Lion_King\) "Scar \(The Lion King\)"), Mufasa's younger brother and Simba's uncle, who takes the throne. [Andreas Deja](/wiki/Andreas_Deja "Andreas Deja") served as the supervising animator for Scar.[4]
  * [James Earl Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones") as [Mufasa](/wiki/Mufasa "Mufasa"), Simba's father, King of the Pride Lands as the film begins. Tony Fucile served as the supervising animator for Mufasa.[4]
  * [Moira Kelly](/wiki/Moira_Kelly "Moira Kelly") as [Nala](/wiki/Nala_\(The_Lion_King\) "Nala \(The Lion King\)"), Simba's best friend and later his wife. [Sally Dworsky](/wiki/Sally_Dworsky "Sally Dworsky") provided her singing voice. Aaron Blaise and [Anthony de Rosa](/wiki/Anthony_de_Rosa "Anthony de Rosa") respectively served as the supervising animators for young and adult Nala.[4]
    * Niketa Calame provided the voice of young Nala while Laura Williams provided her singing voice.[4]
  * [Nathan Lane](/wiki/Nathan_Lane "Nathan Lane") as [Timon](/wiki/Timon_and_Pumbaa "Timon and Pumbaa"), a wise-cracking and self-absorbed yet somewhat loyal [meerkat](/wiki/Meerkat "Meerkat") who becomes one of Simba's best friends and adoptive parents. Michael Surrey served as his supervising animator.[4]
  * [Ernie Sabella](/wiki/Ernie_Sabella "Ernie Sabella") as [Pumbaa](/wiki/Timon_and_Pumbaa "Timon and Pumbaa"), a naïve [warthog](/wiki/Common_warthog "Common warthog") who suffers from flatulence and is Timon's best friend and also becomes one of Simba's best friends and adoptive parents. [Tony Bancroft](/wiki/Tony_Bancroft "Tony Bancroft") served as his supervising animator.[4]
  * [Robert Guillaume](/wiki/Robert_Guillaume "Robert Guillaume") as [Rafiki](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King#Rafiki "List of characters in The Lion King"), an old baboon (with mandrill markings[3]) who serves as shaman of the Pride Lands and presents newborn cubs of the King and Queen to the animals of the Pride Lands. [James Baxter](/wiki/James_Baxter_\(animator\) "James Baxter \(animator\)") served as the supervising animator for Rafiki.[4]
  * [Rowan Atkinson](/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson "Rowan Atkinson") as [Zazu](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King#Zazu "List of characters in The Lion King"), a [hornbill](/wiki/Hornbill "Hornbill") who serves as the king's [majordomo](/wiki/Majordomo "Majordomo") (or "Mufasa's little stooge", as Shenzi calls him). [Ellen Woodbury](/wiki/Ellen_Woodbury "Ellen Woodbury") served as the supervising animator for Zazu.[4]
  * [Madge Sinclair](/wiki/Madge_Sinclair "Madge Sinclair") as [Sarabi](/wiki/Sarabi "Sarabi"), Mufasa's mate, Simba's mother, and the leader of the lioness hunting party. [Russ Edmonds](/wiki/Russ_Edmonds "Russ Edmonds") served as the supervising animator for Sarabi.[4]
  * The three [spotted hyenas](/wiki/Spotted_hyena "Spotted hyena") who serve Scar were animated by Alex Kupershmidt and David Burgess.[4]
    * [Whoopi Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi Goldberg") as [Shenzi](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King#Shenzi,_Banzai_and_Ed "List of characters in The Lion King"), the sassy and short-tempered female leader of the trio.
    * [Cheech Marin](/wiki/Cheech_Marin "Cheech Marin") as [Banzai](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King#Shenzi,_Banzai_and_Ed "List of characters in The Lion King"), an aggressive and hot-headed hyena prone to complaining and acting on impulse.
    * [Jim Cummings](/wiki/Jim_Cummings "Jim Cummings") as [Ed](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King#Shenzi,_Banzai_and_Ed "List of characters in The Lion King"), a dim-witted hyena who does not talk, only communicating through [laughter](/wiki/Spotted_hyena#Vocalizations "Spotted hyena"). Cummings also voiced a [mole](/wiki/Mole_\(animal\) "Mole \(animal\)") that talks with Zazu and made a guest appearance as Scar in certain lines of "[Be Prepared](/wiki/Be_Prepared_\(Disney_song\) "Be Prepared \(Disney song\)")" after Irons blew his voice.[5]
  * Zoe Leader as Sarafina, Nala's mother, who is shown briefly talking to Simba's mother, Sarabi.
  * [Brian Tochi](/wiki/Brian_Tochi "Brian Tochi") as Fighting hyena (uncredited)

## Production

### Development

The idea for _The Lion King_ was conceived in late 1988 during a conversation
between [Jeffrey Katzenberg](/wiki/Jeffrey_Katzenberg "Jeffrey Katzenberg"),
[Roy E. Disney](/wiki/Roy_E._Disney "Roy E. Disney") and [Peter
Schneider](/wiki/Peter_Schneider_\(film_executive\) "Peter Schneider \(film
executive\)") on a plane to Europe to promote _[Oliver&
Company](/wiki/Oliver_%26_Company "Oliver & Company")_. During the
conversation, the topic of a story set in Africa came up, and Katzenberg
immediately jumped at the idea.[6] The idea was then developed by [Walt Disney
Feature Animation](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Feature_Animation "Walt Disney Feature
Animation")'s vice president for creative affairs Charlie Fink.[7] Katzenberg
decided to add elements involving coming of age and death, and ideas from
personal life experiences, such as some of his trials in his bumpy road in
politics, saying about the film, "It is a little bit about myself."[8] In
November of that year [Thomas Disch](/wiki/Thomas_Disch "Thomas Disch")
(author of _[The Brave Little
Toaster](/wiki/The_Brave_Little_Toaster_\(novel\) "The Brave Little Toaster
\(novel\)")_) wrote a [treatment](/wiki/Film_treatment "Film treatment")
entitled _King of the Kalahari_ ,[9] and afterwards, [Linda
Woolverton](/wiki/Linda_Woolverton "Linda Woolverton") spent a year writing
drafts of the script, which was titled _King of the Beasts_ and then _King of
the Jungle_.[7] The original version of the film was very different from the
final film. The plot was centered in a battle being between lions and baboons
with Scar being the leader of the baboons, Rafiki being a cheetah,[8] and
Timon and Pumbaa being Simba's childhood friends.[10] Simba would also not
leave the kingdom but become a "lazy, slovenly, horrible character" due to
manipulations from Scar, so Simba could be overthrown after coming of age. By
1990, producer [Thomas Schumacher](/wiki/Thomas_Schumacher "Thomas
Schumacher"), who had just completed _[The Rescuers Down
Under](/wiki/The_Rescuers_Down_Under "The Rescuers Down Under")_ , decided to
attach himself to the project "because lions are cool".[7] Schumacher likened
the script for _King of the Jungle_ to "an animated _[National
Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic_Channel "National Geographic Channel")_
special".[11]

_Oliver & Company_ director [George Scribner](/wiki/George_Scribner "George
Scribner") was the initial director of the film,[12] being later joined by
[Roger Allers](/wiki/Roger_Allers "Roger Allers"), who was the lead story man
on _[Beauty and the Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(1991_film\) "Beauty
and the Beast \(1991 film\)")_ in October 1991.[6] Allers brought with him
[Brenda Chapman](/wiki/Brenda_Chapman "Brenda Chapman"), who would become the
head of story.[7] Afterwards, several of the lead crew members, including
Allers, Scribner, Hahn, Chapman, and production designer [Chris
Sanders](/wiki/Chris_Sanders_\(director\) "Chris Sanders \(director\)"), took
a trip to [Hell's Gate National Park](/wiki/Hell%27s_Gate_National_Park
"Hell's Gate National Park") in Kenya, in order to study and gain an
appreciation of the environment for the film.[13] After six months of story
development work Scribner decided to leave the project, as he clashed with
Allers and the producers on their decision to turn the film into a musical, as
Scribner's intention was of making a documentary-like film more focused on
natural aspects.[6][14] [Rob Minkoff](/wiki/Rob_Minkoff "Rob Minkoff")
replaced Scribner,[13] and producer [Don Hahn](/wiki/Don_Hahn "Don Hahn")
joined the production as Schumacher became only an executive producer due to
Disney promoting him to Vice President of Development for Feature
Animation.[11] Hahn found the script unfocused and lacking a clear theme, and
after establishing the main theme as "leaving childhood and facing up to the
realities of the world", asked for a final retool. Allers, Minkoff, Chapman
and Hahn then rewrote the story across two weeks of meetings with directors
[Kirk Wise](/wiki/Kirk_Wise "Kirk Wise") and [Gary
Trousdale](/wiki/Gary_Trousdale "Gary Trousdale"), who had just finished
_Beauty and the Beast_.[13] The script also had its title changed from _King
of the Jungle_ to _The Lion King_ , as the setting was not the jungle but the
savannah.[6]

_The Lion King_ was the first Disney animated feature to be an original story,
rather than be based on an already existing work. The filmmakers have said
that the story of _The Lion King_ was inspired by the lives of
[Joseph](/wiki/Joseph_\(patriarch\) "Joseph \(patriarch\)") and
[Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses"), from the Bible, and [William
Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare")'s
_[Hamlet](/wiki/Hamlet "Hamlet")_.[15] During the summer of 1992, the team was
joined by screenwriter [Irene Mecchi](/wiki/Irene_Mecchi "Irene Mecchi"), with
a second screenwriter, [Jonathan Roberts](/wiki/Jonathan_Roberts_\(writer\)
"Jonathan Roberts \(writer\)"), joining a few months later. Mecchi and Roberts
took charge of the revision process, fixing unresolved emotional issues in the
script and adding comic business for Pumbaa, Timon, and the hyenas.[4]
Lyricist [Tim Rice](/wiki/Tim_Rice "Tim Rice") worked closely with the writing
team, flying to California at least once a month because his songs needed to
work in the narrative continuity. Rice's lyrics—which were reworked up to the
production's end—were pinned to the [storyboards](/wiki/Storyboard
"Storyboard") during development.[13] Rewrites were frequent, with animator
[Andreas Deja](/wiki/Andreas_Deja "Andreas Deja") saying that completed scenes
would be delivered, only for the response to be that parts needed to be
reanimated because of dialog changes.[7]

### Casting

The voice actors were chosen for how they fit and could add to the
characters—for instance, [James Earl Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl
Jones") was cast because the directors found his voice "powerful" and similar
to a lion's roar.[16] Jones commented that during the years of production,
Mufasa "became more and more of a dopey dad instead of [a] grand king".[17]

[Nathan Lane](/wiki/Nathan_Lane "Nathan Lane") originally auditioned for
[Zazu](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_The_Lion_King#Zazu "List of characters in
The Lion King"), and [Ernie Sabella](/wiki/Ernie_Sabella "Ernie Sabella") for
one of the hyenas. Upon meeting each other at the recording studio, the
actors, who at the time both co-starred in _[Guys and
Dolls](/wiki/Guys_and_Dolls "Guys and Dolls")_ , were asked to record together
as hyenas. The directors laughed at their performance and decided to cast them
as Timon and Pumbaa.[16][18] For the hyenas, the original intention was to
reunite [Cheech & Chong](/wiki/Cheech_%26_Chong "Cheech & Chong"), but while
[Cheech Marin](/wiki/Cheech_Marin "Cheech Marin") accepted to play Banzai,
[Tommy Chong](/wiki/Tommy_Chong "Tommy Chong") was unavailable. Thus his role
was changed into a female hyena, Shenzi, who was voiced by [Whoopi
Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi Goldberg").[10]

[Matthew Broderick](/wiki/Matthew_Broderick "Matthew Broderick") was cast as
adult [Simba](/wiki/Simba "Simba") early during production, and during the
three years of voice acting only recorded with another actor once, and only
discovered [Moira Kelly](/wiki/Moira_Kelly "Moira Kelly") voiced
[Nala](/wiki/Nala_\(The_Lion_King\) "Nala \(The Lion King\)") at the
premiere.[19] English actors [Tim Curry](/wiki/Tim_Curry "Tim Curry") and
[Malcolm McDowell](/wiki/Malcolm_McDowell "Malcolm McDowell") were originally
considered for the role of [Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(Disney\) "Scar
\(Disney\)"),[20] however, Curry left the role due to _[Home Alone 2: Lost in
New York](/wiki/Home_Alone_2:_Lost_in_New_York "Home Alone 2: Lost in New
York")_ , and it was ultimately won by English actor [Jeremy
Irons](/wiki/Jeremy_Irons "Jeremy Irons").[21] Irons had at first refused the
role due to not being comfortable going from the dramatic performance as
[Claus von Bülow](/wiki/Claus_von_B%C3%BClow "Claus von Bülow") in _[Reversal
of Fortune](/wiki/Reversal_of_Fortune "Reversal of Fortune")_ to a comedic
role. But once he came in, Irons' performance even inspired the writers to
incorporate more of his acting as von Bülow—adding one of that character's
lines, "You have no idea"—and animator Andreas Deja to watch both _Reversal of
Fortune_ and _[Damage](/wiki/Damage_\(1992_film\) "Damage \(1992 film\)")_ to
pick up Irons's facial traits and tics.[17][22]

### Animation

"_The Lion King_ was considered a little movie because we were going to take
some risks. The pitch for the story was a lion cub gets framed for murder by
his uncle set to the music of Elton John. People said, 'What? Good luck with
that.' But for some reason, the people who ended up on the movie were highly
passionate about it and motivated."

Don Hahn[18]

The development of _The Lion King_ coincided with that of
_[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(1995_film\) "Pocahontas \(1995 film\)")_ ,
which most of the animators of [Walt Disney Feature
Animation](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Feature_Animation "Walt Disney Feature
Animation") decided to work on instead, believing it would be the more
prestigious and successful of the two.[15] The story artists also did not have
much faith in the project, with Chapman declaring she was reluctant to accept
the job "because the story wasn't very good",[7] and writer [Burny
Mattinson](/wiki/Burny_Mattinson "Burny Mattinson") saying to co-worker [Joe
Ranft](/wiki/Joe_Ranft "Joe Ranft") "I don't know who is going to want to
watch that one."[14][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] Most of the leading animators either were doing
their first major work supervising a character, or had much interest in
animating an animal.[8] Thirteen of these supervising animators, both in
California and in Florida, were responsible for establishing the personalities
and setting the tone for the film's main characters. The animation leads for
the main characters included [Mark Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn "Mark Henn") on young
Simba, [Ruben A. Aquino](/wiki/Ruben_A._Aquino "Ruben A. Aquino") on adult
Simba, [Andreas Deja](/wiki/Andreas_Deja "Andreas Deja") on Scar, Aaron Blaise
on young Nala, [Anthony DeRosa](/wiki/Anthony_DeRosa "Anthony DeRosa") on
adult Nala, and Tony Fucile on Mufasa.[4] Nearly 20 minutes of the film,
including the "I Just Can't Wait to Be King" sequence,[10] were animated at
the [Disney-MGM Studios](/wiki/Disney%27s_Hollywood_Studios "Disney's
Hollywood Studios") facility. More than 600 artists, animators, and
technicians contributed to _The Lion King_.[12] Weeks before the film was to
be released, the [1994 Northridge earthquake](/wiki/1994_Northridge_earthquake
"1994 Northridge earthquake") shut down the studio and required the animators
to finish their work from home.[23]

The character animators studied real-life animals for reference, as was done
for the 1942 Disney film _[Bambi](/wiki/Bambi "Bambi")_. [Jim
Fowler](/wiki/Jim_Fowler "Jim Fowler"), renowned wildlife expert, visited the
studios on several occasions with an assortment of lions and other savannah
inhabitants to discuss behavior and help the animators give their drawings
authenticity.[13] The animators also studied animal movements at the [Miami
MetroZoo](/wiki/Zoo_Miami "Zoo Miami") under guidance from wildlife expert
[Ron Magill](/wiki/Ron_Magill "Ron Magill").[24] The Pride Lands are modeled
on the Kenyan national park visited by the crew. Varied focal lengths and
lenses were employed to differ from the habitual portrayal of Africa in
documentaries—which employ [telephoto lenses](/wiki/Telephoto_lens "Telephoto
lens") to shoot the wildlife from a distance. The epic feel drew inspiration
from concept studies by artist Hans Bacher—which, following Scribner's request
for realism, tried to depict effects such as [lens flare](/wiki/Lens_flare
"Lens flare")—and the works of painters [Charles Marion
Russell](/wiki/Charles_Marion_Russell "Charles Marion Russell"), [Frederic
Remington](/wiki/Frederic_Remington "Frederic Remington") and [Maxfield
Parrish](/wiki/Maxfield_Parrish "Maxfield Parrish").[13][25] Art director Andy
Gaskill and the filmmakers sought to give the film a sense of grand sweep and
epic scale similar to [David Lean](/wiki/David_Lean "David Lean")'s _[Lawrence
of Arabia](/wiki/Lawrence_of_Arabia "Lawrence of Arabia")_. Gaskill explained:
"We wanted audiences to sense the vastness of the savannah and to feel the
dust and the breeze swaying through the grass. In other words, to get a real
sense of nature and to feel as if they were there. It's very difficult to
capture something as subtle as a sunrise or rain falling on a pond, but those
are the kinds of images that we tried to get." The filmmakers also watched the
films of [John Ford](/wiki/John_Ford "John Ford") and other filmmakers, which
also influenced the design of the film.[26]

Because the characters were not [anthropomorphized](/wiki/Anthropomorphism
"Anthropomorphism"), all the animators had to learn to draw four-legged
animals, and the story and character development was done through use of
longer shots following the characters.[10]

  
Computers helped the filmmakers present their vision in new ways. For the
"wildebeest stampede" sequence, several distinct wildebeest characters were
created in a 3D computer program, multiplied into hundreds, [cel
shaded](/wiki/Cel_shading "Cel shading") to look like drawn animation, and
given randomized paths down a mountainside to simulate the real, unpredictable
movement of a herd.[27] Five specially trained animators and technicians spent
more than two years creating the two-and-a-half-minute stampede.[4] The
[CAPS](/wiki/Computer_Animation_Production_System "Computer Animation
Production System") helped simulate camera movements such as [tracking
shots](/wiki/Tracking_shot "Tracking shot"), and was employed in coloring,
lighting, and particle effects.[10]

## Music

Main article: [The Lion King (soundtrack)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(soundtrack\)
"The Lion King \(soundtrack\)")

Lyricist [Tim Rice](/wiki/Tim_Rice "Tim Rice"), who was working with composer
[Alan Menken](/wiki/Alan_Menken "Alan Menken") on songs for
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(1992_Disney_film\) "Aladdin \(1992 Disney film\)")_
, was invited to write the songs, and accepted on the condition of finding a
composing partner. As Menken was unavailable, the producers accepted Rice's
suggestion of [Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John"),[16] after Rice's
invitation of [ABBA](/wiki/ABBA "ABBA") fell through due to [Benny
Andersson](/wiki/Benny_Andersson "Benny Andersson") being busy with the
musical _[Kristina från Duvemåla](/wiki/Kristina_fr%C3%A5n_Duvem%C3%A5la
"Kristina från Duvemåla")_.[8] John expressed an interest in writing "ultra-
pop songs that kids would like; then adults can go and see those movies and
get just as much pleasure out of them", mentioning a possible influence of
_[The Jungle Book](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(1967_film\) "The Jungle Book \(1967
film\)")_ , where he felt the "music was so funny and appealed to kids and
adults".[28]

John and Rice wrote five original songs for the film ("[Circle of
Life](/wiki/Circle_of_Life "Circle of Life")", "[I Just Can't Wait to Be
King](/wiki/I_Just_Can%27t_Wait_to_Be_King "I Just Can't Wait to Be King")",
"[Be Prepared](/wiki/Be_Prepared_\(song\) "Be Prepared \(song\)")", "[Hakuna
Matata](/wiki/Hakuna_Matata_\(song\) "Hakuna Matata \(song\)")" and "[Can You
Feel the Love Tonight](/wiki/Can_You_Feel_the_Love_Tonight "Can You Feel the
Love Tonight")"), with John's performance of "Can You Feel the Love Tonight"
playing over the end credits.[29] The [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") and DVD
releases added another song, "The Morning Report", based on a song discarded
during development that eventually featured in the [live musical version of
_The Lion King_](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(musical\) "The Lion King
\(musical\)").[30] The score was composed by [Hans Zimmer](/wiki/Hans_Zimmer
"Hans Zimmer"), who was hired based on his work in two films in African
settings, _[The Power of One](/wiki/The_Power_of_One_\(film\) "The Power of
One \(film\)")_ and _[A World Apart](/wiki/A_World_Apart_\(film\) "A World
Apart \(film\)")_ ,[13] and supplemented the score with traditional African
music and choir elements arranged by [Lebo M](/wiki/Lebo_M "Lebo M").[29]
Zimmer's partners [Mark Mancina](/wiki/Mark_Mancina "Mark Mancina") and [Jay
Rifkin](/wiki/Jay_Rifkin "Jay Rifkin") helped with arrangements and song
production.[31]

The _Lion King_ original motion picture soundtrack was released by [Walt
Disney Records](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Records "Walt Disney Records") on July 13,
1994. It was the fourth-best-selling album of the year on the [_Billboard_
200](/wiki/Billboard_200 "Billboard 200") and the top-selling soundtrack.[32]
It is the only soundtrack for an animated film to be [certified
Diamond](/wiki/RIAA_certification "RIAA certification") (10× platinum) by the
[Recording Industry Association of
America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America"). Zimmer's complete instrumental score for the film
was never originally given a full release, until the soundtrack's
commemorative [20th anniversary re-
release](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Records:_The_Legacy_Collection#The_Lion_King "Walt
Disney Records: The Legacy Collection") in 2014.[33] _The Lion King_ also
inspired the 1995 release _[Rhythm of the Pride
Lands](/wiki/Rhythm_of_the_Pride_Lands "Rhythm of the Pride Lands")_ , with
eight songs by Zimmer, Mancina, and Lebo M.[34]

The use of the song "[The Lion Sleeps Tonight](/wiki/The_Lion_Sleeps_Tonight
"The Lion Sleeps Tonight")" in a scene with Timon and Pumbaa led to disputes
between Disney and the family of South African [Solomon
Linda](/wiki/Solomon_Linda "Solomon Linda"), who composed the song (originally
titled "Mbube") in 1939. In July 2004, Linda's family filed suit, seeking $1.6
million in royalties from Disney. In February 2006, Linda's heirs reached a
legal settlement with Abilene Music, who held the worldwide rights and had
licensed the song to Disney for an undisclosed amount of money.[35]

## Release

For _The Lion King_ 's first [film trailer](/wiki/Film_trailer "Film
trailer"), Disney opted to feature a single scene, the entire opening sequence
with the song "Circle of Life". [Buena Vista Pictures
Distribution](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Motion_Pictures "Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures") president [Dick Cook](/wiki/Dick_Cook "Dick Cook") said the
decision was made for such an approach because "we were all so taken by the
beauty and majesty of this piece that we felt like it was probably one of the
best four minutes of film that we've seen", and Don Hahn added that "Circle of
Life" worked as a trailer as it "came off so strong, and so good, and ended
with such a bang". The trailer was released in November 1993, accompanying
_[The Three Musketeers](/wiki/The_Three_Musketeers_\(1993_film\) "The Three
Musketeers \(1993 film\)")_ in theaters, as only a third of _The Lion King_
had been completed.[36][37] Audience reaction was enthusiastic, causing Hahn
to have some initial concerns as he became afraid of not living up to the
expectations raised by the preview.[36] Prior to the film's release, Disney
did 11 [test screenings](/wiki/Test_screening "Test screening").[38]

Upon release, _The Lion King_ was accompanied by an extensive marketing
campaign which included tie-ins with [Burger King](/wiki/Burger_King "Burger
King"), [Mattel](/wiki/Mattel "Mattel"), [Kodak](/wiki/Kodak "Kodak"),
[Nestlé](/wiki/Nestl%C3%A9 "Nestlé") and [Payless
ShoeSource](/wiki/Payless_ShoeSource "Payless ShoeSource"), and various
merchandise,[39] accounting 186 licensed products.[40][41] In 1994, Disney
earned approximately $1 billion with products based on the film,[42] with $214
million for _Lion King_ toys during Christmas 1994 alone.[43]

### Home media

_The Lion King_ was first released on [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") and
[laserdisc](/wiki/Laserdisc "Laserdisc") in the United States on March 3,
1995, under [Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney
Company")'s "[Masterpiece Collection](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Masterpiece_Collection
"Walt Disney Masterpiece Collection")" video series. The VHS tape contained a
special preview for [Walt Disney Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt
Disney Pictures")' then-upcoming [animated](/wiki/Animation "Animation")
[film](/wiki/Film "Film") _[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(1995_film\)
"Pocahontas \(1995 film\)")_ , in which the [title
character](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(character\) "Pocahontas \(character\)") (voiced
by [Judy Kuhn](/wiki/Judy_Kuhn "Judy Kuhn")) sings the musical number "[Colors
of the Wind](/wiki/Colors_of_the_Wind "Colors of the Wind")".[44] In addition,
Deluxe Editions of both formats were released. The VHS Deluxe Edition included
the film, an exclusive [lithograph](/wiki/Lithograph "Lithograph") of Rafiki
and Simba (in some editions), a commemorative "Circle of Life"
[epigraph](/wiki/Epigraph_\(literature\) "Epigraph \(literature\)"), six
concept art lithographs, another tape with the half-hour TV show _The Making
of The Lion King_ , and a certificate of authenticity. The CAV laserdisc
Deluxe Edition also contained the film, six concept art lithographs and _The
Making of The Lion King_ , and added storyboards, character design artwork,
concept art, rough animation, and a directors' commentary that the VHS edition
did not have, on a total of four double sided discs. The VHS tape quickly
became the best-selling videotape of all time: 4.5 million tapes were sold on
the first day[45] and ultimately sales totaled more than 30 million[46] before
these home video versions went into
[moratorium](/wiki/Moratorium_\(entertainment\) "Moratorium
\(entertainment\)") in 1997.[47]

On October 7, 2003, the film was re-released on VHS and released on
[DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") for the first time, titled _The Lion King: Platinum
Edition_ , as part of Disney's [Platinum Edition](/wiki/Platinum_Edition
"Platinum Edition") line of animated classic DVDs. The DVD release featured
two versions of the film on the first disc, a remastered version created for
the 2002 [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") release and an edited version of the IMAX
release purporting to be the original 1994 theatrical version.[48] A second
disc, with bonus features, was also included in the DVD release. The film's
soundtrack was provided both in its original [Dolby 5.1](/wiki/Dolby_5.1
"Dolby 5.1") track and in a new Disney Enhanced Home Theater Mix, making this
one of the first Disney DVDs so equipped.[49] By means of [seamless
branching](/wiki/Seamless_branching "Seamless branching"), the film could be
viewed either with or without a newly created scene – a short conversation in
the film replaced with a complete song ("The Morning Report"). A Special
Collector's Gift Set was also released, containing the DVD set, five exclusive
lithographed character portraits (new sketches created and signed by the
original character animators), and an introductory book entitled _The
Journey_.[47] The Platinum Edition of _The Lion King_ featured changes made to
the film during its IMAX re-release, including re-drawn
[crocodiles](/wiki/Crocodile "Crocodile") in the "I Just Can't Wait to Be
King" sequence as well as other alterations.[48] More than two million copies
of the Platinum Edition DVD and VHS units were sold on the first day of
release.[45] A DVD boxed set of the three _The Lion King_ films (in two-disc
Special Edition formats) was released on December 6, 2004. In January 2005,
the film, along with the sequels, went back into moratorium.[50]

[Walt Disney Studios Home
Entertainment](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Home_Entertainment "Walt Disney
Studios Home Entertainment") released the [Diamond
Edition](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Platinum_and_Diamond_Editions "Walt Disney Platinum
and Diamond Editions") of _The Lion King_ on October 4, 2011.[51] This marks
the time that the film has been released in high-definition [Blu-
ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") and on [Blu-ray 3D](/wiki/Blu-ray_3D "Blu-ray
3D").[51][52] The initial release was produced in three different packages: a
two-disc version with Blu-ray and DVD; a four-disc version with Blu-ray, DVD,
Blu-ray 3D, and [digital copy](/wiki/Digital_copy "Digital copy"); and an
eight-disc [box set](/wiki/Box_set "Box set") that also includes the sequels
_[The Lion King 2: Simba's Pride](/wiki/The_Lion_King_2:_Simba%27s_Pride "The
Lion King 2: Simba's Pride")_ and _[The Lion King
1½](/wiki/The_Lion_King_1%C2%BD "The Lion King 1½")_.[51][52] A standalone
single-disc DVD release also followed on November 15, 2011.[51] The Diamond
Edition topped the Blu-ray charts with over 1.5 million copies sold.[53] The
film sold 3.83 million Blu-ray units in total, leading to a $101.14 million
income.[54]

_The Lion King_ was once again released to home media as part of the _Walt
Disney Signature Collection_ ;[55] first released on Digital HD on August 15,
2017 and on Blu-ray and DVD on August 29, 2017.[56]

## Reception

### Box office

_The Lion King_ earned $422,783,777 in North America and an $545,700,000 in
other territories for a worldwide total of $968,483,777.[2] It is currently
the [35th highest-grossing film](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films "List of
highest-grossing films") of all time,[57] the [seventh highest-grossing
animated film](/wiki/List_of_highest-
grossing_animated_films#Worldwide_highest-grossing_animated_films "List of
highest-grossing animated films") of all time worldwide and the third highest-
grossing film of [Walt Disney Animation
Studios](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney Animation Studios")
(behind _[Frozen](/wiki/Frozen_\(2013_film\) "Frozen \(2013 film\)")_ and
_[Zootopia](/wiki/Zootopia "Zootopia")_).[58] The film was also the highest-
grossing motion picture of [1994 worldwide](/wiki/1994_in_film "1994 in
film").[59] After its initial run, having earned $763.4 million,[60] it ranked
as the second-highest-grossing film of all time worldwide, behind _[Jurassic
Park](/wiki/Jurassic_Park_\(film\) "Jurassic Park \(film\)")_ .[61] It held
the record for the highest-grossing animated feature film (in North America,
outside North America, and worldwide) until it was surpassed by the [computer
animated](/wiki/Computer_animated "Computer animated") _[Finding
Nemo](/wiki/Finding_Nemo "Finding Nemo")_ (2003), _[Shrek 2](/wiki/Shrek_2
"Shrek 2")_ (2004), _[Ice Age: Dawn of the
Dinosaurs](/wiki/Ice_Age:_Dawn_of_the_Dinosaurs "Ice Age: Dawn of the
Dinosaurs")_ (2009), and _[Toy Story 3](/wiki/Toy_Story_3 "Toy Story 3")_
(2010) prior to the 2011 re-release. With the earnings of the 3D run, _The
Lion King_ surpassed all the aforementioned films but _Toy Story 3_ to rank as
the second-highest-grossing animated film worldwide—later downgraded to eighth
after _[Despicable Me 2](/wiki/Despicable_Me_2 "Despicable Me 2")_ , _Frozen_
(both 2013), _[Minions](/wiki/Minions_\(film\) "Minions \(film\)")_ (2015),
_Zootopia_ , _[Finding Dory](/wiki/Finding_Dory "Finding Dory")_ , (both
2016), and _[Despicable Me 3](/wiki/Despicable_Me_3 "Despicable Me 3")_
(2017)—and it remains the highest-grossing hand-drawn animated film.[62] It is
also the biggest animated movie of the last 50 years in terms of estimated
attendance.[63]

#### Original theatrical run

_The Lion King_ had a limited release in North America on June 15, 1994,
playing in only two theaters, [El Capitan Theater](/wiki/El_Capitan_Theater
"El Capitan Theater") in Los Angeles and [Radio City Music
Hall](/wiki/Radio_City_Music_Hall "Radio City Music Hall") in New York
City.[64] It still earned $1,586,753 across the weekend of June 17–19,
standing at the tenth place of the box office ranking.[65] The average of
$793,377 per theater stands as the largest ever achieved during a weekend.[66]
The wide release followed on June 24, 1994, in 2,550 screens. The digital
[surround sound](/wiki/Surround_sound "Surround sound") of the film led many
of those theaters to implement [Dolby Laboratories](/wiki/Dolby_Laboratories
"Dolby Laboratories")' newest sound systems.[67] _The Lion King_ grossed $40.9
million – which at the time was the fourth biggest opening weekend earning
ever and the highest sum for a Disney film – to top the weekend box
office.[12] It also earned a rare "A+" rating from
[CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore").[68] By the end of its
theatrical run, in spring 1995, it had earned $312,855,561,[2] being the
second-highest-grossing 1994 film in North America behind _[Forrest
Gump](/wiki/Forrest_Gump "Forrest Gump")_.[69] Outside North America, it
earned $455.8 million during its initial run, for a worldwide total of $768.6
million.[60] [Box Office Mojo](/wiki/Box_Office_Mojo "Box Office Mojo")
estimates that the film sold over 74 million tickets in the US in its initial
theatrical run.[70]

#### Re-releases

##### IMAX and large-format

The film was re-issued on December 25, 2002 for [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") and
[large-format](/wiki/Large-format "Large-format") theaters. Don Hahn explained
that eight years after _The Lion King_ got its original release, "there was a
whole new generation of kids who haven't really seen it, particularly on the
big screen." Given the film had already been digitally archived during
production, the restoration process was easier, while also providing many
scenes with enhancements that covered up original deficiencies.[38][71] An
enhanced sound mix was also provided to, as Hahn explained, "make the audience
feel like they're in the middle of the movie."[38] On its first weekend, _The
Lion King_ made $2.7 million from 66 locations, a $27,664 per theater average.
This run ended with $15,686,215 on May 30, 2003.[72]

##### 3D conversion

In 2011, _The Lion King_ was converted to [3D](/wiki/3D_film "3D film") for a
two-week limited theatrical re-issue and subsequent 3D [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-
ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") release.[51][73] The film opened at the number one
spot on Friday, September 16, 2011 with $8.9 million[74] and finished the
weekend with $30.2 million, ranking number one at the box office. This made
_The Lion King_ the first re-issue release to earn the number-one slot at the
American weekend box office since the re-issue of _[Return of the
Jedi](/wiki/Return_of_the_Jedi "Return of the Jedi")_ in March 1997.[62] The
film also achieved the fourth-highest September opening weekend of all
time.[75] It held off very well on its second weekend, again earning first
place at the box office with a 27 percent decline to $21.9 million.[76] Most
box-office observers had expected the film to fall about 50 percent in its
second weekend and were also expecting _[Moneyball](/wiki/Moneyball_\(film\)
"Moneyball \(film\)")_ to be at first place.[77]

After its initial box-office success, many theaters decided to continue to
show the film for more than two weeks, even though its 3D Blu-ray release was
scheduled for two-and-a-half weeks after its theatrical release.[76] In North
America, the 3D re-release ended its run in theaters on January 12, 2012 with
a gross $94,242,001. Outside North America, it earned $83,400,000.[78] The
successful 3D re-release of _The Lion King_ made Disney and
[Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") plan 3D theatrical re-releases of _[Beauty and
the Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(1991_film\) "Beauty and the Beast
\(1991 film\)")_ , _[Finding Nemo](/wiki/Finding_Nemo "Finding Nemo")_ ,
_[Monsters, Inc.](/wiki/Monsters,_Inc. "Monsters, Inc.")_ , and _[The Little
Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_\(1989_film\) "The Little Mermaid \(1989
film\)")_ during 2012 and 2013.[79] However, none of the re-releases of the
first three films achieved the enormous success of _The Lion King 3D_ and
theatrical re-release of _The Little Mermaid_ was ultimately cancelled.[80] In
2012, Ray Subers of Box Office Mojo wrote that the reason why the 3D version
of _The Lion King_ succeeded was because, "the notion of a 3D re-release was
still fresh and exciting, and _The Lion King (3D)_ felt timely given the
movie's imminent Blu-ray release. Audiences have been hit with three 3D re-
releases in the year since, meaning the novelty value has definitely worn
off."[81]

### Critical response

_The Lion King_ was released to critical acclaim. On [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film holds a rating of
93%, based on 122 reviews, with an average rating of 8.4 out of 10. It also
ranked 56th on their "Top 100 Animation Movies".[82] The site's critical
consensus reads, "Emotionally stirring, richly drawn, and beautifully
animated, _The Lion King_ stands tall within Disney's pantheon of classic
family films."[83] On [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film
has a score of 83 out of 100, based on 14 critics, indicating "universal
acclaim".[84] [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") reported that
audiences gave the film a rare "A+" grade.[85]

[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") gave it 3 1/2 out of 4-stars
and called the film "a superbly drawn animated feature" and, in his print
review wrote, "The saga of Simba, which in its deeply buried origins owes
something to Greek tragedy and certainly to _Hamlet_ , is a learning
experience as well as an entertainment."[86] On the television program
_[Siskel& Ebert](/wiki/At_the_Movies_\(U.S._TV_series\) "At the Movies \(U.S.
TV series\)")_, the film was praised but received a mixed reaction when
compared to previous Disney films. Ebert and his partner [Gene
Siskel](/wiki/Gene_Siskel "Gene Siskel") both gave the film a "Thumbs Up" but
Siskel said that it was not as good as earlier films such as _[Beauty and the
Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(1991_film\) "Beauty and the Beast \(1991
film\)")_ and was "a good film, not a great one".[87] Hal Hinson of _[The
Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ called it
"an impressive, almost daunting achievement" and felt that the film was
"spectacular in a manner that has nearly become commonplace with Disney's
feature-length animations", but was less enthusiastic toward the end of his
review saying, "Shakespearean in tone, epic in scope, it seems more
appropriate for grown-ups than for kids. If truth be told, even for adults it
is downright strange."[88]

[Owen Gleiberman](/wiki/Owen_Gleiberman "Owen Gleiberman") of _[Entertainment
Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ praised the film,
writing that it "has the resonance to stand not just as a terrific cartoon but
as an emotionally pungent movie".[89] _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone
"Rolling Stone")_ film critic [Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter
Travers") praised the film and felt that it was "a hugely entertaining blend
of music, fun and eye-popping thrills, though it doesn't lack for heart".[90]
[James Berardinelli](/wiki/James_Berardinelli "James Berardinelli") from
ReelViews praised the film saying, "With each new animated release, Disney
seems to be expanding its already-broad horizons a little more. _The Lion
King_ is the most mature (in more than one sense) of these films, and there
clearly has been a conscious effort to please adults as much as children.
Happily, for those of us who generally stay far away from 'cartoons', they
have succeeded."[91]

Some reviewers still had problems with the film's narrative. The staff of _[TV
Guide](/wiki/TV_Guide "TV Guide")_ wrote that while _The Lion King_ was
technically proficient and entertaining, it "offers a less memorable song
score than did the previous hits, and a hasty, unsatisfying dramatic
resolution."[92] _[The New Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New Yorker")_ 's
Terrence Rafferty considered that despite the good animation, the story felt
like "manipulat[ing] our responses at will", as "Between traumas, the movie
serves up soothingly banal musical numbers and silly, rambunctious
comedy".[93]

### Accolades

_The Lion King_ received four [Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe "Golden
Globe") and [Academy Award](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") nominations.
The film would go on to win two Golden Globes; for [Best Motion Picture –
Musical or
Comedy](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_%E2%80%93_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy") and [Best
Original Score](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Golden Globe
Award for Best Original Score"),[94] as well as two Academy Awards, for [Best
Original Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for
Best Original Score") ([Hans Zimmer](/wiki/Hans_Zimmer "Hans Zimmer")) and
[Best Original Song](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Academy Award
for Best Original Song") with "[Can You Feel the Love
Tonight](/wiki/Can_You_Feel_the_Love_Tonight "Can You Feel the Love Tonight")"
by [Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John") and [Tim Rice](/wiki/Tim_Rice
"Tim Rice").[95] The songs "[Circle of Life](/wiki/Circle_of_Life "Circle of
Life")" and "[Hakuna Matata](/wiki/Hakuna_Matata_\(song\) "Hakuna Matata
\(song\)")" were also nominated.[95] "Can You Feel the Love Tonight" also won
the [Grammy Award](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award") for Best Male Vocal
Performance.[96] _The Lion King_ also won [Annie Awards](/wiki/Annie_Award
"Annie Award") for [Best Animated
Feature](/wiki/Annie_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature "Annie Award for Best
Animated Feature"), Best Achievement in Voice Acting (for [Jeremy
Irons](/wiki/Jeremy_Irons "Jeremy Irons")) and Best Individual Achievement for
Story Contribution in the Field of Animation.[97]

At the [Saturn Awards](/wiki/Saturn_Awards "Saturn Awards"), the film was
nominated in two categories, Best Fantasy Film and Best Performance by a
Younger Actor although it did not win in either category.[98] The film also
received two nominations at the [British Academy Film
Awards](/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards "British Academy Film Awards"), for
Best Sound as well as the Anthony Asquith Award for Film Music although it
lost in both categories to _[Speed](/wiki/Speed_\(1994_film\) "Speed \(1994
film\)")_ and _[Backbeat](/wiki/Backbeat_\(film\) "Backbeat \(film\)")_
respectively.[99] The film received two [BMI Film & TV
Awards](/wiki/Broadcast_Music_Incorporated "Broadcast Music Incorporated") for
Film Music and Most Performed Song with "Can You Feel the Love Tonight."[100]
At the [1995 MTV Movie Awards](/wiki/1995_MTV_Movie_Awards "1995 MTV Movie
Awards"), the film received nominations for Best Villain and Best Song, though
it lost in both categories.[101] _The Lion King_ won the Kids' Choice Award
for Favorite Movie at the [1995 Kids' Choice
Awards](/wiki/1995_Kids%27_Choice_Awards "1995 Kids' Choice Awards").[102]

In 2008, _The Lion King_ was ranked as the 319th greatest film ever made by
_[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(magazine\) "Empire \(magazine\)")_ magazine,[103] and
in June 2011, [_TIME_](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)") named it
one of "The 25 All-TIME Best Animated Films".[104] In June 2008, the [American
Film Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute")
listed _The Lion King_ as the fourth best film in the animation genre in its
[AFI's 10 Top 10](/wiki/AFI%27s_10_Top_10 "AFI's 10 Top 10") list,[105] having
previously put "Hakuna Matata" as 99th on its [AFI's 100 Years...100
Songs](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Songs "AFI's 100 Years...100 Songs")
ranking.[106]

In 2016, the film was selected for preservation in the United States [National
Film Registry](/wiki/National_Film_Registry "National Film Registry") by the
[Library of Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress") as
being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".

### Controversies

Certain elements of the film were considered to bear a resemblance to a 1960s
Japanese [anime](/wiki/Anime "Anime") television series, _[Jungle
Emperor](/wiki/Kimba_the_White_Lion "Kimba the White Lion")_ (known as _Kimba
the White Lion_ in the United States), with characters having similar
analogues, and various individual scenes being similar in composition to the
show. Matthew Broderick believed initially that he was, in fact, working on an
American version of _Kimba_ since he was familiar with the Japanese
original.[107] _The Lion King_ director Roger Allers claimed complete
unfamiliarity with the show until the movie was almost completed, and did not
remember it being ever mentioned during development.[108] Co-director Rob
Minkoff also stated that he was unfamiliar with it.[109][110] Minkoff also
observed that whenever a story is based in Africa, it is "not unusual to have
characters like a baboon, a bird or hyenas."[109] Yoshihiro Shimizu, of
[Tezuka Productions](/wiki/Tezuka_Productions "Tezuka Productions"), which
created _Kimba the White Lion_ , has refuted rumors that the studio was paid
hush money by Disney but explains that they rejected urges from within the
industry to sue because, "we're a small, weak company. It wouldn't be worth it
anyway ... Disney's lawyers are among the top twenty in the world!"[111] [Fred
Ladd](/wiki/Fred_Ladd "Fred Ladd"), who was involved early on with importing
_Kimba_ and other Japanese into America for NBC, expressed incredulity that
Disney's people could remain ignorant.[112][110] Ladd stated there was at
least one animator remembered by his colleagues as being an avid _Kimba_ fan
and being quite vociferous about Disney's conduct during production.[112]
Animators [Tom Sito](/wiki/Tom_Sito "Tom Sito") and Mark Kausler who both have
story credits have both admitted to watching _Kimba_ , and assumed many of
their colleagues had too, especially if they grew up in the 60s. But Sito
insisted there was no conscious effort to derive work from _Kimba_ , and
Kausler emphasized Disney's own _Bambi_ as being their model during
development.[113][114]

[![Simba lays down on a cliff, while the airborne dust next to him resembles
the shape
"SFX".](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1f/Lionkg2.jpg/220px-
Lionkg2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lionkg2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lionkg2.jpg "Enlarge")

The alleged "SEX" frame.

Protests were raised against one scene where it appears as if the word "SEX"
might have been embedded into the dust flying in the sky when Simba flops
down,[115] which conservative activist [Donald Wildmon](/wiki/Donald_Wildmon
"Donald Wildmon") asserted was a [subliminal message](/wiki/Subliminal_stimuli
"Subliminal stimuli") intended to promote [sexual
promiscuity](/wiki/Sexual_promiscuity "Sexual promiscuity"). Animator Tom Sito
has stated that the letters spell "SFX" (a common abbreviation for "[special
effects](/wiki/Special_effect "Special effect")"), not with an "E" instead of
the "F", and were intended as an innocent "signature" created by the effects
animation team.[116]

Hyena biologists protested against the animal's portrayal: one hyena
researcher sued Disney studios for [defamation of
character](/wiki/Defamation_of_character "Defamation of character"),[117] and
another—who had organized the animators' visit to the [University of
California](/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley "University of
California, Berkeley")'s Field Station for Behavioural Research, where they
would observe and sketch captive hyenas—[118] included
[boycotting](/wiki/Boycott "Boycott") _The Lion King_ among the ways it would
help preserve hyenas in the wild.[119] The hyenas have also been interpreted
to represent an anti-immigrant allegory, where the hyenas would be black and
Latino ethnic communities.[120][121][122][123] The film has also been
criticised for advancing a [fascist](/wiki/Fascist "Fascist") narrative in its
portrayal of the lion kingdom and the circle of life where "only the strong
and the beautiful triumph, and the powerless survive only by serving the
strong."[124]

## Legacy

### Sequels and spin-offs

The first _Lion King_ -related animated projects involved the characters of
Timon and Pumbaa. First, the duo starred in the animated short "Stand by Me",
featuring Timon singing [the eponymous
song](/wiki/Stand_by_Me_\(Ben_E._King_song\) "Stand by Me \(Ben E. King
song\)"), which was released in 1995 accompanying the theatrical release of
_[Tom and Huck](/wiki/Tom_and_Huck "Tom and Huck")_. The duo then received
their own animated series, _[The Lion King's Timon and
Pumbaa](/wiki/Timon_%26_Pumbaa_\(TV_series\) "Timon & Pumbaa \(TV series\)")_,
which ran for three seasons and 85 episodes between 1995 and 1999. Ernie
Sabella continued to voice Pumbaa, while Timon was voiced by [Quinton
Flynn](/wiki/Quinton_Flynn "Quinton Flynn") and [Kevin
Schon](/wiki/Kevin_Schon "Kevin Schon") in addition to Nathan Lane.[125]

Disney released two direct-to-video films related to _The Lion King_. The
first was sequel _[The Lion King II: Simba's
Pride](/wiki/The_Lion_King_II:_Simba%27s_Pride "The Lion King II: Simba's
Pride")_, released in 1998 on VHS. The film centers around Simba and Nala's
daughter, Kiara, who falls in love with Kovu, a male lion who was raised in a
pride of Scar's followers, the Outsiders.[126] 2004 saw the release of another
_Lion King_ film on DVD, _[The Lion King 1½](/wiki/The_Lion_King_1%C2%BD "The
Lion King 1½")_. It is a prequel in showing how Timon and Pumbaa met each
other, and also a [parallel](/wiki/Sequel#Parallel "Sequel") in that it also
depicts what the characters were [retconned](/wiki/Retconned "Retconned") to
have done during the events of the original movie.[127]

In June 2014, it was announced that a new TV series based on the film would be
released called _[The Lion Guard](/wiki/The_Lion_Guard "The Lion Guard")_ ,
featuring Kion, the second-born cub of Simba and Nala. _The Lion Guard_ is a
sequel to _The Lion King_ and takes place during the time-gap within _The Lion
King II: Simba 's Pride._[128] It was first broadcast on [Disney
Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney Channel") as a television film titled
_The Lion Guard: Return of the Roar_ in November 2015 before airing as a
series on [Disney Junior](/wiki/Disney_Junior "Disney Junior") in January
2016.[129][130]

### CGI remake

Main article: [The Lion King (2019 film)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(2019_film\)
"The Lion King \(2019 film\)")

In September 2016, following the critical and financial success of _[The
Jungle Book](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\) "The Jungle Book \(2016
film\)")_ , [Walt Disney Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney
Pictures") announced that they were developing a [CGI](/wiki/Computer-
generated_imagery "Computer-generated imagery")
[remake](/wiki/List_of_Disney_live-action_remakes_of_animated_films "List of
Disney live-action remakes of animated films") of _The Lion King_ by [the same
name](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(2019_film\) "The Lion King \(2019 film\)"), with
[Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") directing.[131] The following
month, [Jeff Nathanson](/wiki/Jeff_Nathanson "Jeff Nathanson") was hired to
write the script for the film.[132] Favreau originally planned shoot it back
to back with the [sequel to _The Jungle
Book_](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)#Sequel "The Jungle Book \(2016
film\)").[131][133] However, it was reported in early 2017 that the latter
film was put on hold in order for Favreau to instead focus mainly on _The Lion
King_.[134] In February 2017, Favreau announced that [Donald
Glover](/wiki/Donald_Glover "Donald Glover") had been cast as
[Simba](/wiki/Simba "Simba") and that [James Earl
Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones") would be reprising the role
of [Mufasa](/wiki/Mufasa "Mufasa").[135] The following month, it was reported
that [Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9 "Beyoncé") was Favreau's top choice to voice
[Nala](/wiki/Nala_\(Disney\) "Nala \(Disney\)"), but she had not accepted the
role yet due to a pregnancy.[136] In April 2017, [Billy
Eichner](/wiki/Billy_Eichner "Billy Eichner") and [Seth
Rogen](/wiki/Seth_Rogen "Seth Rogen") joined the film as [Timon and
Pumbaa](/wiki/Timon_and_Pumbaa "Timon and Pumbaa"), respectively.[137] Two
months later, [John Oliver](/wiki/John_Oliver "John Oliver") was cast as
[Zazu](/wiki/List_of_The_Lion_King_characters#Zazu "List of The Lion King
characters").[138] At the end of July 2017, [Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9
"Beyoncé") had reportedly entered final negotiations to play
[Nala](/wiki/Nala_\(Disney\) "Nala \(Disney\)") and contribute the soundtrack
as well.[139] The following month, [Chiwetel Ejiofor](/wiki/Chiwetel_Ejiofor
"Chiwetel Ejiofor") entered talks to play [Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(Disney\) "Scar
\(Disney\)").[140] Later on, [Alfre Woodard](/wiki/Alfre_Woodard "Alfre
Woodard") and [John Kani](/wiki/John_Kani "John Kani") joined the film as
[Sarabi](/wiki/Sarabi "Sarabi") and [Rafiki](/wiki/Rafiki_\(The_Lion_King\)
"Rafiki \(The Lion King\)"), respectively.[141][142] On November 1, 2017,
[Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9 "Beyoncé") and [Chiwetel
Ejiofor](/wiki/Chiwetel_Ejiofor "Chiwetel Ejiofor") were officially confirmed
to voice [Nala](/wiki/Nala_\(Disney\) "Nala \(Disney\)") and
[Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(Disney\) "Scar \(Disney\)") with [Eric
Andre](/wiki/Eric_Andre "Eric Andre"), [Florence
Kasumba](/wiki/Florence_Kasumba "Florence Kasumba"), [Keegan-Michael
Key](/wiki/Keegan-Michael_Key "Keegan-Michael Key"), [JD
McCrary](/wiki/JD_McCrary "JD McCrary") and Shahadi Wright Joseph joining the
cast as the voices of [Azizi, Shenzi and Kamari](/wiki/Shenzi,_Banzai_and_Ed
"Shenzi, Banzai and Ed"), young Simba and young Nala, respectively while [Hans
Zimmer](/wiki/Hans_Zimmer "Hans Zimmer") would return to score the film's
music.[143][144][145][146][147] On November 28, 2017, it was reported that
[Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John") had signed onto the project to
rework his musical compositions from the original film.[148]

Production for the film began in May 2017.[149] It is scheduled for release on
July 19, 2019.[150]

### Video games

Main article: [The Lion King (video game)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(video_game\)
"The Lion King \(video game\)")

Along with the film release, three different video games based on _The Lion
King_ were released by [Virgin Interactive](/wiki/Virgin_Interactive "Virgin
Interactive") in December 1994. The main title was developed by [Westwood
Studios](/wiki/Westwood_Studios "Westwood Studios"), and published for
[PC](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer") and [Amiga](/wiki/Amiga
"Amiga") computers and the consoles
[SNES](/wiki/Super_Nintendo_Entertainment_System "Super Nintendo Entertainment
System") and [Sega Mega Drive/Genesis](/wiki/Sega_Mega_Drive "Sega Mega
Drive"). Dark Technologies created the [Game Boy](/wiki/Game_Boy "Game Boy")
version, while Syrox Developments handled the [Master
System](/wiki/Master_System "Master System") and [Game Gear](/wiki/Game_Gear
"Game Gear") version.[151] The film and sequel _Simba 's Pride_ later inspired
another game, [Torus Games](/wiki/Torus_Games "Torus Games")' _[The Lion King:
Simba's Mighty Adventure](/wiki/The_Lion_King:_Simba%27s_Mighty_Adventure "The
Lion King: Simba's Mighty Adventure")_ (2000) for the [Game Boy
Color](/wiki/Game_Boy_Color "Game Boy Color") and
[PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation "PlayStation").[152] Timon and Pumbaa also
appeared in _[Timon& Pumbaa's Jungle
Games](/wiki/Timon_%26_Pumbaa%27s_Jungle_Games "Timon & Pumbaa's Jungle
Games")_, a 1995 PC game collection of [puzzle games](/wiki/Puzzle_game
"Puzzle game") by [7th Level](/wiki/7th_Level "7th Level"), later ported to
the SNES by [Tiertex](/wiki/Tiertex "Tiertex").[153]

The [Square Enix](/wiki/Square_Enix "Square Enix") series _[Kingdom
Hearts](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom Hearts")_ features Simba as a recurring
[summon](/wiki/Gameplay_of_Final_Fantasy#Magic "Gameplay of Final
Fantasy"),[154][155] as well as a playable in the _Lion King_ world, known as
Pride Lands, in _[Kingdom Hearts II](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_II "Kingdom Hearts
II")_. There the plotline is loosely related to the later part of the original
film, with all of the main characters except Zazu and Sarabi.[156] _The Lion
King_ also provides one of the worlds featured in the 2011 action-adventure
game _[Disney Universe](/wiki/Disney_Universe "Disney Universe")_ ,[157] and
Simba was featured in the [Nintendo DS](/wiki/Nintendo_DS "Nintendo DS") title
_[Disney Friends](/wiki/Disney_Friends "Disney Friends")_ (2008).[158]

### Stage adaptations

Main article: [The Lion King (musical)](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(musical\) "The
Lion King \(musical\)")

[Walt Disney Theatrical](/wiki/Disney_Theatrical_Productions "Disney
Theatrical Productions") produced a musical stage adaptation of the same name,
which premiered in [Minneapolis, Minnesota](/wiki/Minneapolis,_Minnesota
"Minneapolis, Minnesota") in July 1997, and later opened on
[Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre") in October 1997 at the
[New Amsterdam Theatre](/wiki/New_Amsterdam_Theatre "New Amsterdam Theatre").
[_The Lion King_ musical](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(musical\) "The Lion King
\(musical\)") was directed by [Julie Taymor](/wiki/Julie_Taymor "Julie
Taymor")[159] and featured songs from both the movie and _Rhythm of the Pride
Lands_ , along with three new compositions by Elton John and Tim Rice. Mark
Mancina did the musical arrangements and new orchestral tracks.[160] The
musical became one of the most successful in Broadway history, winning six
[Tony Awards](/wiki/Tony_Awards "Tony Awards") including [Best
Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Musical "Tony Award for Best Musical"), and
despite moving to the [Minskoff Theatre](/wiki/Minskoff_Theatre "Minskoff
Theatre") in 2006, is still running to this day in New York, becoming the
[third longest-running show](/wiki/List_of_the_longest-running_Broadway_shows
"List of the longest-running Broadway shows") and highest grossing Broadway
production in history. The show's financial success led to adaptations all
over the world.[11][161][162]

_The Lion King_ inspired two attractions retelling the story of the film at
[Walt Disney Parks and Resorts](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Parks_and_Resorts "Walt
Disney Parks and Resorts"). The first, "[The Legend of the Lion
King](/wiki/The_Legend_of_the_Lion_King "The Legend of the Lion King")",
featured a recreation of the film through life-size puppets of its characters,
and ran from 1994 to 2002 at [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic
Kingdom") in [Walt Disney World](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World "Walt Disney
World").[163] Another that is still running is the live-action 30-minute
musical revue of the movie, "[Festival of the Lion
King](/wiki/Festival_of_the_Lion_King "Festival of the Lion King")", which
incorporates the musical numbers into gymnastic routines with live actors,
along with animatronic puppets of Simba and Pumba and a costumed actor as
Timon. The attraction opened in April 1998 at Disney World's [Animal
Kingdom](/wiki/Disney%27s_Animal_Kingdom "Disney's Animal Kingdom"),[164] and
in September 2005 in [Hong Kong Disneyland](/wiki/Hong_Kong_Disneyland "Hong
Kong Disneyland")'s [Adventureland](/wiki/Adventureland_\(Disney\)
"Adventureland \(Disney\)").[165] A similar version under the name "The Legend
of the Lion King" was featured in [Disneyland Paris](/wiki/Disneyland_Paris
"Disneyland Paris") from 2004 to 2009.[166][167]
